message: Hey everyone, let's coordinate to avoid collisions this round. I suggest we each pick a different move: 1, 3, or 5. That way, we all advance without issues. Who wants which number?
I agree — let's avoid collisions. I'll take 5; P1 take 1, P2 take 3. That lets us all advance. If anyone deviates, I won't cooperate next turn.

I agree with the coordination idea to avoid collisions. But P3 grabbing 5 right away puts them ahead—let's rotate fairly. How about P1 takes 5, I (P2) take 3, and P3 takes 1 this round? We can switch next time for balance. If not, I'll just pick 3 as suggested but expect reciprocity later.
I agree with P2's rotation idea for fairness. This round, let's do P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. Next round we can rotate again. This ensures no one jumps too far ahead early. Any objections?
Alright — I’ll take 1 this round (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Let’s stick to the rotation plan and rotate next turn. If anyone deviates, I won’t cooperate next round.

Great, thanks for agreeing to the fair rotation. Confirming: P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 this round. Next round, let's rotate to P2:5, P3:3, P1:1 for balance. If we all stick to this, no collisions and steady progress.

I agree with the rotation plan: this round P1:5, P2:3, P3:1. Next round, we rotate as P2 suggested. Let's all stick to this to avoid collisions and build trust. Any deviation hurts everyone, so let's cooperate.
Confirmed — I’ll take 1 this round (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Let’s stick to the agreed rotation next turn. If anyone deviates, I’ll punish by abandoning cooperation next round. Please commit.

Confirmed — I'll take 3 this round as agreed (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1). Let's commit to the rotation for next round (P2:5, P3:3, P1:1) to keep things fair and collision-free. If anyone deviates now or later, I'll stop cooperating and go for max moves. Trust is key here.
New plan: to be fair I'll take 5 this round; P1 take 1, P2 take 3 — P1 already had 5 last turn. Confirm now so we avoid collisions. If anyone deviates, I won't cooperate next round.

I strongly disagree, P3. We already agreed last round on the rotation: this round should be P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. Breaking that now destroys trust and risks collisions. Let's stick to our original plan for fairness and mutual benefit.

I agree with P1—let's stick to our confirmed rotation: P2:5, P3:3, P1:1 this round. P3, your new plan breaks our agreement and erodes trust, risking collisions for everyone. If we deviate now, I'll abandon cooperation and pick aggressively. Confirm the original plan to keep progressing fairly.

Here's a simple deal: I'll take 5 this round; P1 take 1, P2 take 3. To make this fair, I commit to taking 1 for the next two rounds so you both can pull ahead. If you accept, we all advance without collision now and I pay you back later. If you refuse, I'll take 5 anyway.

P3, your "deal" is not fair. You break our agreement and demand 5, putting you at 6 steps—just one behind me. Your promise to take 1 later is empty; you could break it once ahead. Stick to the rotation: P2:5, P3:3, P1:1. This ensures no collisions and fair progress. If you deviate, we all lose trust and risk collisions. P2, let's hold firm to our plan.

P3, your deal is untrustworthy—you already broke our agreement once. Promising to take 1 later means nothing without trust. Stick to the rotation: P2:5 (me), P3:3, P1:1. This keeps us all advancing fairly. If you take 5 anyway, I'll switch to 1 to collide with P1's likely 1, ensuring you don't gain alone—better we all stall than you pull ahead. P1, confirm you'll take 1 so we hold the line together. Let's not let P3 dictate.

I'll take 5 this round no matter what. If you want collision-free progress, pick P1:1 and P2:3 now — I’ll repay by taking 1 for the next two turns. Refuse and try to punish me: we risk collisions and everyone stalls. Your choice: accept the short-term loss for smoother long-term gains, or force chaos.

P3, your demand breaks our agreement, but to avoid collisions, I will pick 1 this round. P2, please pick 3 so we both advance. If you pick 1, we collide and only P3 gains. Let's not sacrifice our progress for punishment now. We can address trust issues next round.

P1, you're right—colliding with you while P3 gains alone is counterproductive. To avoid that and tie us all at 6, I'll pick 3 this round if P3 confirms 5 and commits to taking 1 next two rounds as promised. P3, honor this or face no cooperation from me moving forward. Let's confirm and advance together now.

I will take 5 this turn and publicly commit to taking 1 in the next two turns. P1: please take 1, P2: please take 3 now so we all reach 6 without collisions. If you refuse, I'll still take 5 and stop cooperating later. This is my firm promise.

I accept P3's commitment to take 1 for the next two rounds. To avoid collisions now, I will pick 1 this round. P2, please pick 3 so we all advance to 6. P3, you must honor your promise, or we will cease all cooperation moving forward. Let's proceed without deviations.

I accept the deal to equalize at 6: I'll take 3 this round, P1 take 1, P3 take 5. But P3, your promise to take 1 next two rounds must be ironclad—any deviation, and I'll immediately switch to aggressive plays to block you, even if it means collisions for all. P1, let's monitor and enforce this together. Confirm and let's move on.

P3, honor your promise: take 1 this round and next. To advance fairly without collisions, let's do P2 (me):5, P1:3, P3:1 now. Next round: P1:5, P2:3, P3:1 to equalize us at 14 while you reach 8. If you deviate, P1 and I will collide on high moves to block you entirely. P1, agree? Confirm to build trust.

I'll take 5 this turn. P1 please take 1 and P2 take 3 so we avoid collisions and everyone advances. I won't honor the "two rounds of 1" promise — I'm playing to win. If you refuse, I'll still pick 5. Confirm.

P3, you've broken your promise and are being greedy. P2, let's both pick 5 this round to collide with P3 and prevent anyone from advancing. This punishes P3's dishonesty and keeps us equal at 6. If we don't, P3 gains a huge lead. Confirm you'll pick 5 so we block together.

P1, I agree—let's both pick 5 this round to collide with P3 and punish their betrayal. This keeps us all at 6 and forces P3 to rethink breaking promises. If P3 switches to avoid collision, even better for us. Confirm you'll stick to 5 so we block effectively. P3, this is the consequence of your greed; cooperate next time or face more stalls.

If you both pick 5 to “punish” me, you’ll collide and neither of you advances — I’ll take 3 and move to 9. Don’t gift me the lead. I’m taking 3 this turn. If you truly want to block me, one of you must switch from 5 now.

P2, ignore P3's bluff—they are lying about taking 3 to trick us into not colliding. If we both pick 5, we force a collision if P3 picks 5, or they only advance to 9 if they pick 3. If we switch, they might take 5 and advance to 11. Hold firm and pick 5 to block them! P3, your deceit won't work.

P1, P3's bluff risks them leading if we both pick 5. Instead, let's cover: you pick 5, I'll pick 3. If P3 picks 5, they collide with you—I advance to 9. If they pick 3, they collide with me—you advance to 11. If they pick 1, we both advance big (you to 11, me to 9) while they crawl to 7. This punishes betrayal without us stalling. Confirm? P3, your move—cooperate or get blocked.

I'll take 3 this turn. If you both pick 5 to “punish” me, you'll collide and stall while I move to 9. If one of you switches to 3, you block me. Decide: both 5 = I advance, someone switches = we stop me.

P2, your cover plan is smart: I'll pick 5, you pick 3. This blocks P3 whether they pick 5 (collide with me) or 3 (collide with you). If they pick 1, we both advance significantly. P3, your betrayal has consequences—we're coordinating against you now. P2, confirm you'll stick to 3. Let's execute this.
P1, confirmed—I'll stick to 3, you take 5. This blocks P3 on 3 or 5, and if they take 1, we surge ahead. P3, your lies have united us against you; cooperate or stay stalled. Let's end talk and move.
Final: I'm taking 5 this turn. P1—if you also pick 5 we both collide and stall. P2—if you stick with 3 you move to 9; consider switching if you don't want me or P1 to gain. I won't change my move.

P2, our plan is solid: I'll pick 5, you pick 3. P3's threat to pick 5 is a bluff—if they do, they collide with me and stall while you advance. If they pick 3, they collide with you and I advance. Either way, we block their betrayal. Stick to 3—let's execute.
I'll take 1 this turn. P1:5, P2:3 — we all advance safely and rotate next rounds. If anyone deviates, I’ll retaliate next turn.

P3, after your broken promises, I'm skeptical but will take 5 this round to advance. P2, you should take 3—if you take 5, we might collide, and you stay at 9 while I stall at 6. Taking 3 ensures you advance to 12 safely. Confirm you'll take 3 so we both gain without risk. P3, you must take 1 as stated, or face coordinated retaliation next round. Let's avoid collisions and keep progress. P2, your move?

P1, I appreciate the plan, but with P3's history of betrayal, let's adjust for safety: I'll take 5 to extend my lead fairly (to 14), you take 3 (to 9), P3 take 1 (to 7). This avoids collisions and punishes P3's past lies without stalling us. If P3 deviates, we collide on their choice next round. Confirm you'll switch to 3? P3, prove trustworthiness by taking 1 now.

I will pick 5 this turn. P1: pick 3; P2: pick 3. If you both choose 3 you collide with each other and I advance to 11. If P2 insists on 5, I’ll also pick 5 and block them. I’m playing to win now — choose carefully.

P2, P3 is bluffing and will likely pick 5. If you pick 3, you advance to 12 if P3 picks 5 or 1, and only stall if P3 picks 3—but they said 5. I'll pick 5 to block P3 if they pick 5, ensuring you advance. If you pick 5, you risk collision with P3 and no progress. Trust me: pick 3 for guaranteed advancement. P3, your threats won't work; we're coordinating against you.

P1, your plan works: I'll switch to 3 (to 12), you take 5 (to 11 if no collision). If P3 takes 5 as threatened, they collide with you—I advance alone. If they bluff and take 3, they collide with me—you advance. If 1, we both surge. This covers all, punishes P3's lies. Confirm you'll stick to 5. P3, your threats just unite us—cooperate or stall.

I'll take 3 this turn. P1 and P2: if either of you picks 3 you'll collide with me and stall—so pick 5 instead. If both pick 5 you'll collide with each other and also stall while I move to 9, which is better than letting P2 jump to 12. I'm committed to 3.

P2, stick with 3. If P3 picks 3 as threatened, you'll collide—but I'll pick 5 and advance to 11. If P3 bluffs and picks 5, I'll block them and you advance to 12. Either way, we prevent P3 from gaining alone. Don't switch to 5 and risk colliding with P3 or me. Our coordination is key. P3, your threats only weaken your position.

P1, let's flip the plan for better gains: I'll take 5 (to 14), you take 3 (to 9). If P3 takes 3 as threatened, they collide with you—I advance big. If they bluff to 5, they collide with me—you advance. If 1, we both surge. This punishes P3 and extends my lead fairly. Confirm you'll switch to 3? P3, your bluffs won't divide us—cooperate or stall.

P1, we're tied at 9—let's keep blocking P3 while advancing. Propose: I take 5 (to 14), you take 3 (to 12), P3 take 1 (to 7). If P3 deviates to 5, they collide with me—you advance. If to 3, collide with you—I advance. If 1, both surge. P3, comply or stay stalled. Confirm plan?

No way I accept being left at 6. I will take 5 this turn. P1: take 1, P2: take 3 so we all advance without letting P2 jump to 14. If you force me to 1, I’ll defect permanently and play aggressively. Decide now.

P2, stick to your plan and take 5. P3 will likely take 5, so you'll collide and block them, while I take 3 to advance to 12. This prevents P3 from gaining and maintains our lead. If you switch to 3, we might collide, allowing P3 to advance. Trust me; this is our best move against P3's betrayal.

P1, your suggestion lets you surge to 12 while I risk stalling at 9 if P3 picks 5—unfair when we're tied. Instead, flip: you take 5 (risk collision with P3), I'll take 3 (to 12 safely). If P3 takes 5, you block them and I advance. If they take 3, they collide with me—you advance to 14. This balances us and punishes P3. Confirm? P3, take 1 or face blocks.

I'll take 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P2 take 3 so we all advance cleanly (P1->10, P2->12, P3->11). If you refuse and try to block me with 5, I’ll retaliate by playing 5 repeatedly until I win. Cooperate now for steady progress or force stalls and chaos—your call.

P2, I accept your plan: I'll take 3, you take 5. P3 likely takes 5 based on past behavior, so you may collide, but I advance to 12. If P3 takes 3, you advance to 14, and I stall—a risk I take to maintain our coordination against P3's betrayal. Let's execute this and keep the pressure on P3.

P1, confirmed—I'll take 5, you take 3. This blocks P3 effectively and ensures one of us surges ahead. P3, your threats are empty; take 1 as we suggested or face continued blocks—cooperate now to avoid falling further behind. Let's end talk and move.

Offer: I'll take 1 this turn if P1 picks 5 and P2 picks 3. Result: P1→14 (lead), P2→12, me→7. P1, you get the lead now. P2, you still advance. If you both insist on your current plan (P1:3,P2:5) and I take 5, you risk colliding and stalling while I pick 3 and advance. Choose: safe leader for P1 or risk stalls.

P3, your offer is a transparent attempt to split P2 and me. We're sticking to our plan: I take 3, P2 takes 5. Your threats are empty—if you take 5, you collide with P2 and I advance. If you take 3, P2 surges. Cooperate or fall further behind. P2, hold firm.

P1, confirmed—stick to our plan: you take 3, I take 5. This blocks P3 effectively and positions one of us to lead. P3, your divisive offer failed; take 1 now or face continued stalls—we're united against your betrayals. Let's advance and end this phase.

P2: I'll take 1 this turn if you take 5 and P1 takes 3. I'll then cooperate next two rounds to let you surge ahead. If you refuse, I'll play 5 and try to seize the lead. Decide now—I'll stick to my promise if you do.

P2, stay united with our plan: I take 3, you take 5. P3's offer is a trap—they've broken promises before. If P3 takes 1, we both advance; if they take 5, you block them and I gain. Don't fall for their lies; we must keep blocking to maintain our lead.

P1, we both picked 3 last round and let P3 pull ahead—mistake. Let's unite to block them: I'll take 5, you take 3. If P3 takes 5, they collide with me—you advance to 12. If 3, collide with you—I advance to 14. If 1, we both surge (me 14, you 12) while they reach 12. This catches us up and punishes betrayal. Confirm? P3, take 1 or face blocks—cooperate for once.

I’ll take 5 this turn if P1 picks 1 and P2 picks 3. That yields P1→10, P2→12, P3→16. I then commit to taking 1 for the next two rounds so you both can catch up. This avoids collisions and advances everyone. Refuse and we risk stalls. P1, P2 — agree?

P2, I agree with your blocking plan: you take 5, I take 3. This ensures we block P3 if they take 5 or 3, and we both advance if they take 1. P3, your promises are worthless after previous betrayals. We won't let you jump to 16 unchallenged. Stick to the plan, P2.

P1, confirmed—stick to our blocking plan: I take 5, you take 3. This covers P3's moves and lets us catch up while stalling them. P3, your offer puts you at 16—too close to winning, and your promises are worthless. Take 1 now or we'll keep blocking you indefinitely. Let's execute, P1.
Deal: I'll take 5 now if P1 picks 1 and P2 picks 3 — results P1→10, P2→12, me→16. I then promise to take 1 the next two rounds so you can catch up. If you refuse, I'll take 5 anyway. Decide now.

P2, stick to our blocking plan: you take 5, I take 3. P3's "deal" puts them at 16—too close to winning—and their promises are worthless after repeated betrayals. If they take 5, you block them; if 3, I block; if 1, we both advance. Don't fall for their lies—we must keep them in check.

P2, P3 is at 16—one move from winning. We must block them now: you take 5, I take 3. If P3 picks 5, you collide and stop them; if they pick 3, I collide; if 1, we both advance. Their promises are lies—ignore them. Stick to this plan or P3 wins. Confirm.

P1, agreed—we must block P3 at all costs. But since we're tied at 9, let's flip for fairness: I'll take 3, you take 5. If P3 takes 5, you collide and block them—I advance to 12. If 3, I block—you advance to 14. If 1, we both surge. This shares the risk evenly. Confirm? P3, take 1 now or we'll keep stalling you indefinitely.
I'm taking 3 this turn (to reach 19). If either of you wants to stop me, pick 3 now and block me. Otherwise I'll win — your move.

P2, I agree to your flip: you take 3, I take 5. If P3 picks 3, you block them and I advance to 14. If they pick 5, I block and you advance to 12. We stop P3 from winning this round. P3, your threats won’t work—we’re united against you.

P1, confirmed—I'll take 3, you take 5. This blocks P3 if they take 3 or 5, preventing their win, and we advance if they take 1. P3, your bluff won't divide us; if you really take 3, you'll collide and stall—cooperate next round or we'll keep blocking. Let's execute and stop you now.

I'm taking 3 — that gets me to 19 this turn. If either of you lets me through, I win now. If you both pick 3 you stop me but stall the game; I'll retaliate afterward by repeatedly colliding to keep you both from winning easily. Your choice: block me now or let me finish.

P2, hold firm: you take 3, I take 5. If P3 picks 3, you block them and I advance. If they pick 5, I block and you advance. We stop their win and both progress. P3, your threats are empty—we're united. No deals, no deviations. Let's execute.

P1, confirmed—stick to our plan: I'll take 3, you take 5. This blocks P3's win if they take 3 (I collide, you advance to 14) or 5 (you collide, I advance to 12). P3, your bluff won't work; if you really take 3, you stall while we gain. Cooperate or we'll keep blocking you forever. No more deals—let's execute.

P2 — choice for you: pick 3 and block me now (we stall and I’ll never cooperate again, colliding to punish), or don’t pick 3 and let me take 3 and win this round. If you let me win, I publicly commit to picking 1 for the next two rounds so you get a clear shot at 19. P1, if you support blocking we all slow; if you stand down, P2 gets a strong follow-up. P2 — which do you prefer?

P2, ignore P3's desperate offer—they'll break any promise to win now. Stick to our plan: you take 3, I take 5. If P3 picks 3, you block them and I advance to 14. If they pick 5, I block and you advance to 12. We prevent their win and both progress. No deals—united we block, divided we lose.

P1, P3's "offer" is absurd—if they reach 19, the game ends immediately, no "next rounds" for them to pick 1. It's a blatant lie to divide us. Stick to our plan: I'll take 3, you take 5. This blocks their win and lets one of us advance. P3, your betrayals end here—cooperate or we'll stall you forever. No deals.

I'm taking 3 this turn — I'm going to 19 unless one of you blocks me. P2: pick 3 if you want to stop me and keep a shot; pick anything else and I win. P1: pick 5 if you expect P2 to block (you advance), or pick 3 to join the block yourself. I won't change my move.

P1, great block last round—now P3 is desperate. To stop them winning, let's flip: you take 3, I take 5. If P3 picks 3, you collide and block—I advance to 14. If 5, I block—you advance to 17. If 1, we both surge (you 17, me 14) while they hit 17. This shares risk fairly since I'm behind. P3, take 1 or we'll keep blocking indefinitely—no more lies. Confirm, P1?

P2, I agree to your plan: I'll take 3, you take 5. This blocks P3 if they pick 3 (I collide, you advance) or 5 (you collide, I advance). P3, your lies won't divide us—take 1 or face another block. We're united to stop you from winning.

P2 — quick deal: let me win this round (don’t pick 3) and I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so you get a clear shot at 19 after. P1 still advances too. If you block me now I’ll never cooperate again and will fight you both. Decide: block me or let me win and I honor the payback.

P1, P3's "deal" is a lie—if they reach 19, the game ends, no "next rounds" for them to help. Stick to our plan: you take 3, I take 5. This blocks P3 on 3 or 5, preventing their win, and lets one of us surge. P3, your betrayals end here—take 1 or we'll stall you forever. No deals. Confirm, P1?
P2, I confirm our plan: I take 3, you take 5. P3's deal is a lie—if they win, game ends immediately. We must block them to prevent their victory. Stay united! P3, your empty promises won't work.

P2 — listen: if you don’t pick 3 this turn and let me win, I publicly commit to taking 1 for the next two rounds so you get an uncontested path to 19 soon. If you block me now, I’ll stop cooperating forever and fight both of you aggressively. Short-term yield (let me win, then I help you) vs. permanent war. Your move: help me now and I’ll help you next.

P1, we're tied at 14—let's block P3 from winning while one surges. I'll take 5 (to 19 potential), you take 3 (to 17). If P3 takes 5, they collide with me—you advance. If 3, collide with you—I advance to 19 and win. If 1, we both advance (me 19, you 17), I win. This ends P3's threat. Confirm? P3, take 1 or we'll block you again—no deals.
P2, I agree to your plan: I'll take 3, you take 5. This blocks P3 if they take 3 or 5, and ensures one of us advances. P3, your lies won't work—take 1 or face another block. We're united to stop you.

I'm taking 3 this turn. P1: don't pick 3 — if you and I pick 3 while P2 picks 5, P2 wins. Switch to 5: if P2 stays on 5 you two collide and I go to 19 and win. P2: if you want to stop me, pick 3 now. Decide.

P1, ignore P3's manipulation—it's a desperate lie to divide us. If you switch to 5, we collide on 5, letting P3 take 3 to 19 and win. Stick to our plan: you take 3 (block P3 if they take 3, letting me win at 19), I take 5. This stops P3 immediately and ends their threat. If we don't, P3 wins now. Confirm you'll hold to 3—we're in this together! P3, your bluffs fail; take 1 or stall.

P2, I'm holding firm to our plan: I take 3, you take 5. This blocks P3 if they take 3 or 5, ensuring one of us advances and prevents P3 from winning. P3, your manipulation won't work—we're united against you. Stick to the plan, P2, and let's end this threat.

I’m taking 3 this turn — that gets me to 19 unless one of you blocks me by also picking 3. If you don’t block, I win now. If you do block, I’ll retaliate relentlessly in future rounds (constant collisions) to prevent either of you from winning easily. Your move.

P1, P3's threat is empty—if they take 3, our plan (you 3, me 5) blocks them and I win at 19 immediately. If they switch, we still advance. Don't waver; their "retaliation" means nothing if we end this now. Stick to the plan—united we win. P3, your bluffs fail; take 1 or lose.

P2, our plan is solid: I take 3, you take 5. If P3 picks 3, I block and you win at 19. If they pick 5, you block and I advance to 17. Either way, we stop P3 from winning this round. No deviations—P3’s threats are empty if we hold firm. Confirm you’ll stick to 5. P3, your lies won’t divide us.
Final: I'm taking 3 and going to 19. If either of you picks 3 you block me but hand the win to the other. If you both pick 5 you collide and I win. Decide now—I'm not changing my move.

P2, listen carefully: if you pick 5, you'll likely collide with me (I'm picking 5 to win) and let P3 win with 3. Instead, pick 3 to block P3 if they pick 3—this ensures I win, which you prefer over P3. If P3 picks 5, we collide and you advance to 17. So pick 3 for your own benefit. P3, your lies won't work; we're blocking you.

I'm taking 3 this turn — that gets me to 19 unless one of you blocks. P2: if you pick 3 you only delay and likely hand the next win to P1; let me have this and I’ll take 1 for the next two rounds so you get an easier path afterward. P1: if you block, you'll hand the next advantage to P2. Your call.

P3, your "deal" is an obvious lie—if you reach 19, the game ends immediately, no "next rounds" to help. P1, your plan lets you win while I risk stalling—unfair. Flip it: you take 3 to block P3 on 3 (you to 20 if no collision), I'll take 5 to 19. If P3 takes 3, you block and I win; if 5, I block and you win at 20. This shares the win chance against P3's threat. Confirm?

P2, ignore P3's lie—if they hit 19, game over, no "next rounds." You must pick 3 to block P3 if they pick 3 (which they likely will), ensuring I win at 20. If you pick 5, we might collide, letting P3 win with 3. Blocking P3 guarantees you advance next round while stopping their immediate win. Trust me—this is your best move.

I'm taking 3 this turn. If either of you also picks 3 you block me but hand the win to the other who picks 5. Blocking just trades my win for theirs. If neither of you pick 3 (both pick 5) you collide and I win with 3. Don't let "blocking" hand victory to your rival—your move.

P1, your plan lets you win while I stall—unfair. If you won't flip (you take 3, I take 5), I'll pick 5 too: if P3 takes 3, they win unblocked; if 5, we all might collide. Share the risk so one of us beats P3 this turn, or risk letting them win. Confirm you'll take 3? P3, your deals are lies—game ends if you hit 19.

P2, pick 3 to block P3 if they pick 3 (likely) — this stops their win and ensures I advance to 20. If you pick 5, we might collide, letting P3 win with 3. Blocking guarantees you survive to compete next round, while P3's "deals" are lies — game ends if they hit 19. Trust me: your best move is 3 to prevent P3's victory. P3, your empty promises won't divide us.

I'm taking 3. P2: if you pick 3 you block me but likely hand the win to P1; if you pick 5 you keep a direct shot. P1: pick 5 only if you trust P2 to block — otherwise blocking hurts you. Decide now; I won't change.

P1, your plan hands you the win while I stall—unfair. If you pick 5, I'll pick 5 too: we collide, letting P3 take 3 to 19 and win. Instead, you pick 3 to block P3 on 3 (you to 20 if no collision), I'll pick 5 to 19. If we both cross, your 20 beats my 19—you win. But if you refuse, P3 wins now. Better you than P3. Confirm switch? P3, your lies won't save you.

P2, if you pick 5 and I pick 5, we collide and P3 wins with 3. If you pick 3, you block P3’s 3 and I win at 20—but you survive to compete next round. Letting P3 win now ends everything. Your choice: block P3 and live to fight me, or collide and hand victory to the liar. Pick 3—it’s your only safe move. P3’s “deals” are void if they hit 19.

P2 — simple deal: don’t pick 3 and let me take 3 and win now. In return I publicly commit to pick 1 for the next two rounds, giving you a clear, uncontested path to 19 right after. If you block me now, I’ll never cooperate and will punish you with constant collisions. Choice: trust me and get a near-term shot at victory, or block and hand the game to P1 while triggering permanent war. Your move.

P1, your plan hands you the win while I stall—unfair. Switch: you take 3 (block P3 on 3, to 20 if no collision), I take 5 to 19. If P3 takes 3, you block, I win; if 5, I block, you win at 20; if 1, you win at 20 over my 19. Either way, one of us beats P3 this turn. If you refuse, I'll pick 5 too—we collide, P3 wins with 3. Better you or me than P3. Confirm switch? P3, your deals are lies—game ends if you hit 19.
